projectDesc.p: The project DHARMA has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement no 809994).

prefixDef.p: Public URIs with the prefix bib to point to a Zotero Group Library named ERC-DHARMA whose data are open to the public.
Internal URIs using the part prefix to point to person elements in the DHARMA_IdListMembers_v01.xml file.

revisionDesc.change: Updating toward the encoding template v03

div.p:
svasti śrimaN vijayāditya-satyāśraya-śri-prithivi-bhallabha-mahārā
ja-Athirāja-paramēśvara-bhaṭāraḷa vijayarājya-saṁvatsaraṁbu
prathama-r ē ā jyaṁbuna rēṇḍ-agun ēṇḍu vaṇarājuL vaṁganūru
viṣayaṁbu Ēḷa v a ā ri p a ā ḷa caḷki ḷēnṟurājula niṭuru paṭu
gana Ēḷucu gamuṇḍalli gōtraṁbuna vēḷāla-guṇḍiya pāṟa veneyaṟēgariki
r a ā camānaṁbuna Ēbhadi maṟuntuṟlu Iccinadi dēni
ki sākṣi gōṇaya bōḷu kundābākaḷu vēdari bōḷu vēlaya
ṟuneduṁbālu paṭṭi gāpuḷu janna-p a ā ṟu Ājjava-pāṟu
vērasāma
pa
pā ṟu vaccamuḷu dēniki vakraṁbu vaccuvāru pañca
mahāpātaka-saṁyuktul aguḷca

lg.l:
yō harēt i a vasu
ndharāṁ
ṣaṣ thi ṭi -va ruṣa rṣa sahasrāṇi

app.note: The scribe omitted one akṣara in the word saṁvatsaraṁbu of the same line, and he might therefore simply have forgotten two akṣaras in this word. There might be a chance, however, that it is sort of an abbreviated way of writing the biruda. The editors state in a footnote that saṁya has to be read satyāśraya.

app.rdg: śrī- pri pṛ thivī bha va llabha

app.note: In many cases the ansuvāra is written on top of the akṣara it is supposed to be pronounced before instead of after in Telugu inscriptions. It is noteworthy, that the first anusvāra is written on top of the ⟨sa⟩ and the second on top of the ⟨bu⟩ in this word; but the second akṣara has to be read ⟨ṁbu⟩. The same occurs with ⟨ṁbu⟩ in line six. The editors state in a footnote that the word has to be read saṁvatsaraṁbu.

The anusvāra is written on top of the ⟨ga⟩ but pronounced before this akṣara as is often the case in Telugu inscriptions; the reading vaṁga is furthermore secured by other inscriptions (see
334 56 B 3 ). The editors state in a footnote that the word has to be read as vaṁganūru. Regarding the misspellings in line 2 and line 1 (if it is not an abbreviation) a further slip at this spot is possible as well.
This word may be connected with skt. pāla-. It occurs in a few other Telugu inscriptions.

The length of the vowel is rather probable since the structure of the first compound member seems to be a result of the typical metathesis in Telugu, i.e. ḷē- from *iḷa or *eḷV plus the Telugu ending -nṟu; the cognate may be Kannaḍa eḷa 'tenderness, youth' (
284 ), e.g. in eḷa-arasar 'prince' (
179 referring to
2 7 ) that represents the same construction as ḷēnṟu-rāju. The title also appears in at least two other inscriptions (
333 56 A 4 and
98 23-24 ).

app.rdg:
niṭ u ū ru paṭu
gana gānu

app.note:
The name seems to go back to *veni-ay(y)a-ṟē-gāru (confer similar instances where *Xi-ay(y)a is realized as Xey(y)a as in bādeyya (
329 598 ); this realization is one of several options). The element ṟē- is the result of the Telugu metathesis and corresponds to Kannaḍa eṟe 'ruler'. As for the first element *veni- compare vini
yaṇa (
234-236 42G 21-22 ). Both elements may go back to Telugu vinu 'sky'.
The editors' reading represents a Prakrit form of Sanskrit varasvāmī or parasvāmī and might be what was intended.
The ambiguity in reading the first akṣara results from its being very close to ⟨ṭa⟩, ⟨ḍa⟩, ⟨da⟩, or a slightly damaged ⟨va⟩ in this inscription.
As to my knowledge, there is no grammatical option to integrate ⟨ḷcu⟩ into the verbal form. It therefore must be seen as yet another lapsus of the scribe.

app.rdg: ṣaṣ thi ṭi r-va ruṣa rṣa
app.note: The standard appearance of the verse contains the multiplicativum ṣaṣṭis 'sixty times'. Yet, in the standard spelling a consonant is doubled after a repha. Hence, there is a certain chance that the scribe wrote ṣaṣṭi-varṣasahasrāṇi 'sixty year-thousands'.

div.p:
The scribe did not differentiate between long ⟨°ī⟩ and short ⟨°i⟩. Since this could reflect an actual indifference towards distinguishing vowel length in pronunctiation in this respect, the text was not "normalized". In the scribe's ductus the akṣaras ⟨da⟩ and ⟨ṭa⟩ look alike. He further does not differentiate between ⟨dha⟩ and ⟨tha⟩ both of which are written with a dot in the middle. A viṣaya or nāṇḍu with the name vaṁganūr is mentioned (and written clearly) in
14 2 and also mentioned in
604 2 . The place name consists of the elements vaṁgan(V) and ūru "village"; the first element could go back to Telugu vaṁka "crooked", compare Kannaḍa vaṁka "the winding course of a stream" (
1370 ), with locative suffix. Hence, the place name could mean "village at the river curve". The modern village Vaṁganūr actually is situated at a curve of the Pennar river. It might hence be possible that the viṣaya was also simply called vaṁgana "at the river curve" (
56 B 3 ) if it wasn't really vaṁganūr. The attested vaṁgaru on the other hand (
56 C 3 ) very probably is a misspelling for vaṁganūru because of etymological reasons.
As for the place name kundābākaḷu, a bāka-nāṇḍu is mentioned in
67-70 12 2-3 . The inscription stops after the first third of line 11 although the imprecation verse is not completed and plenty of space is still left. It is possible that the inscription originally continued in the next line but regarding the flaws that the scribe seems to be responsible for it is also possible that he simply forgot to complete his task.

The inscription was noted in A. R. No. B 10 of 1959-1960 and first published by K. V. Ramesh and S. S. Ramachandra Murthy with annotations and a picture (
334-335 56 C ).
